Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Wave, Surge, and Wind Hazard and Damage from Super Typhoon Haiyan

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Rapid Response Grant (RAPID) project is to collect perishable damage, wave, storm surge, debris, and wind data from Super Typhoon Haiyan that made landfall in Philippines. Super Typhoon Haiyan may have been the strongest land falling tropical cyclone in recorded history. The data on wave, surge, and debris are characteristics of the storm and not highly dependent on the structures. Wind damage in the town of Tacloban and island of Samar sustained catastrophic wind and wave/surge damage. The Principal investigator will work in conjunction with representatives of Japan and Philippines Engineering Societies in collection of data.

Because Super Typhoon Haiyan was (probably) the strongest recorded land falling storm in history, it represents one end of the envelope for design purposes. For this reason, ascertaining both the hazard and damage levels will give a good estimate of the types and quantities of damage, and failure mechanisms that might occur in the United States. Very strong low frequency wave/surge motions were noted during this storm with resulting catastrophic damage. Since these loadings do not exist in present standards, an improved understanding of the generation mechanisms, hazard levels, and structural damage will help to improve predictions of loading climate, and can be used to validate damage models. Documentation of damage of commercial buildings may permit assessment of wind speed intensity through reverse engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project documented wave and surge levels and damage in Leyte and Samar, Philippines, following Typhoon Haiyan which, with estimated 195mph sustained winds, was the strongest landfalling storm of the satellite era. In concert with other researchers from the Japan Society of Civil Engineers and the Philippine Institute of Civil Engineers, we created a database of inundation levels in both open coasts and protected regions, and surveyed residential and commercial building damage. Wave runup inundation on some open ocean coasts exceeded 10m above sea level, and was particularly large in regions not protected by a fringing reef. This caused catastrophic damage to many houses and buildings in regions that were thought to be safe from inundation. The motion of large objects such as boulders was used to infer strength of flows, and demonstrated that this wave and surge inundation not only reached high elevations, but with extremely large velocities.

 

Wind damage was also extreme, with more than 90% of buildings in the most affected areas suffering catastrophic roof loss during the storm. Long span steel truss roofs, including those constructed just prior to Haiyan, performed particularly poorly, with collapsed trusses and walls common. With other researchers from the American Society of Civil Engineers, we helped in creating a publicly available database to document damage suffered during the storm.

 

Results from this project show that the most extreme storms produce wind, wave, and surge that can reach areas thought to be protected and can cause severe damage to even well-engineered structures. Some of these processes, such as wave runup inundation, are not well accounted for in existing design standards, but can provide the largest loads in some locations. Loading and design standards need to account for these processes to ensure resilience in future storms.
